title: Pricing for Coordination in Dynamic Games
abstract: We investigate the use of pricing mechanisms as a means to achieve a socially optimal feedback control strategy among selfish agents. We show that the problem of determining whether the social planner can establish the desired feedback control as a Nash equilibrium among the agents is convex. In addition, we discuss methods for minimizing the difference between the cost incurred under pricing and the socially optimal cost, incorporating a notion of fairness through weighted pricing, and reducing the impact of free-riding. We study the problem of pricing to induce investment in security measures that insure stability of a multinetwork. Problem Statement •Noncooperative, non-zero sum game with p selfish agents, one social planner, and dynamics u x = Ax + P p=1 B i u i
